Option A: This trajectory follows closely along the 50th percentile, indicating normal growth patterns according to WHO standards.

 

Option B: Although this trajectory starts near the 15th percentile, it remains consistently parallel to the standard growth curves, suggesting stable growth that remains proportionate over time, albeit at a lower percentile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric health assessments, growth charts are critical tools. They help healthcare providers monitor a child's growth over time, comparing their progress against standardized percentile curves. A trajectory like "C", which falls below the 3rd percentile, warrants further investigation to determine the cause of the poor growth and to initiate appropriate interventions.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PSGN

 

  • The clinical picture points to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. (PSGN).
  • PSGN is characterised by sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.
  • Most children recover entirely from hematuria and proteinuria within 3-6 weeks of the beginning of nephritis after a throat infection with nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci. However, between 3 and 10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

 

Light microscopy reveals larger, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix in PSGN. In the early stages, polymorph neutrophils (PMN) infiltrate.

 

Immunofluorescence: "Lumpy-bumpy" IgG and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and

 

Electron microscopy- humps are seen on epithelial side of glomerular basement membrane

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrolithiasis: Nephrolithiasis will have features of kidney stones in ultrasound. Symptoms: dysuria, hypogastric pain, hematuria & repeated urinary infections.

 

Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve: this is one of the cause of distal urinary tract obstruction in boys. Clinical features, abnormal urinary stream, dribbling, palpable bladder & recurrent UTI.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Blood pressure of the patient will be normal. Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine

 

Urine is the best sample to send for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus infection among the following options.

 

CMV can be detected using either PCR or culture. Saliva, urine, or blood can be used to collect the sample.

 

  • Clinical features:
    1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
    2. Prematurity
    3. Microcephaly
    4. Intracranial calcifications (Periventricular)
    5. Chorioretinitis
    6. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
    7. Hepatosplenomegaly
    8. Jaundice
    9. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
    10. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
    11. Mild increases in CSF protein

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver biopsy: In any of the TORCH infection, liver biopsy is not the investigation of choice. Live biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option B. CSF: In case of suspected meningitis we do CSF, not in TORCH profile

 

Option C. Blood: In this question blood sample is not the right option. If the question was regarding diagnosing of congenital varicella infection, then the right choice would be ANTI – VZV – ANTIBODY

 

Educational Objective:


Urine is the most appropriate sample for the detection of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection using PCR, particularly in the neonatal period.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

 

The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter. A pulse oximeter is commonly used to measure the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of the blood and monitor heart rate. While it is useful in many clinical settings, including neonatal care, it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

 

Cyanosis is a clinical sign that appears when there is at least 5 g/dL of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood. A pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation but does not directly assess the color changes in the skin or mucous membranes, which are crucial for identifying cyanosis. Moreover, in conditions like severe anemia, a patient might have a low oxygen saturation without appearing cyanosed.

 

However, measuring central cyanosis requires clinical observation and is not reliably detected by a pulse oximeter. Therefore, a pulse oximeter is not used to measure central cyanosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Uses of a Pulse Oximeter:

 

Option A. In CPR: Pulse oximeters are used to monitor oxygenation and the effectiveness of chest compressions and ventilation during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

 

Option B. To know about apnea: Pulse oximeters can indicate apnea by detecting bradycardia and desaturation episodes.

 

Option C. In neonatal resuscitation: Pulse oximeters are vital for assessing the newborn's oxygenation status during resuscitation and adjusting oxygen therapy as needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt without a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with stable vitals and ECG showing PSVT. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

     

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in a stable child begins with pharmacological intervention rather than immediate cardioversion. Adenosine is the drug of choice for PSVT due to its ability to temporarily block the atrioventricular node, effectively terminating the arrhythmia.

 

The initial dose of adenosine recommended is 0.1 mg/kg given as a rapid IV bolus over 1-3 seconds. If there is no response, subsequent doses can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg, and if necessary, 0.3 mg/kg can be administered under monitored conditions. Rapid bolus administration is essential, followed by a 5-10 ml of saline flush to ensure the drug reaches systemic circulation quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardioversion: Cardioversion is typically reserved for cases where the patient is unstable or when pharmacological management fails. In a stable patient, the initial approach is to use adenosine to terminate the PSVT without the need for electrical intervention.

 

Option B. Adenosine 0.3 mg per kg: While this dosage of adenosine can be used if initial doses do not work, it is not the starting dose. The initial dose should be lower, at 0.1 mg/kg, to minimize potential adverse effects.

 

Option C. Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg: This dose of adenosine is appropriate for a second attempt if the initial dose (0.1 mg/kg) does not resolve the PSVT. It is not the first-line dose but can be escalated to after the initial dose fails.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable PSVT in children, adenosine is the first-line treatment, starting at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg. If this dose is ineffective, the dose may be escalated in subsequent attempts.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum calcium

 

In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is essential to assess the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia. Infants of diabetic mothers are predisposed to conditions like hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

 

  • Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium level below 8 mg/dL in term infants and below 7 mg/dL in preterm infants. This condition often occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers. In utero, the higher levels of maternal serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, leading to hypocalcemia after birth. If untreated, hypocalcemia can result in neurological symptoms, including seizures, headaches, and neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium: Serum potassium is not directly related to hypoglycemia in infants of diabetic mothers. The primary concern in this scenario is hypocalcemia rather than potassium imbalance.

 

Option B. CBC: While a complete blood count (CBC) can provide useful information, it is not specifically related to the metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers. Serum calcium is a more appropriate investigation in this context.

 

Option C. Serum chloride: Serum chloride levels do not have a direct connection with hypoglycemia or the other metabolic issues typically seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Therefore, it is not the most relevant test in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In infants of diabetic mothers, it is crucial to monitor serum calcium levels alongside blood glucose to detect and manage hypocalcemia, which can have significant neurological implications if untreated.

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

     

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation is a safety feature designed to release pressure when it exceeds a certain limit to prevent barotrauma to the patient. This valve typically releases at a pressure range of 30-40 cm of water (H2O). This pressure setting helps ensure that the air is delivered to the patient safely without causing excessive force that could damage the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is commonly treated with stimulant medications, which are the first line of treatment. The main drugs of choice include methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine. These medications work by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving concentration and reducing impulsivity and hyperactivity.

 

Atomoxetine, although not a stimulant, is also used as a treatment option for ADHD. It works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is considered a non-stimulant alternative, especially useful in patients who may not respond well to stimulants or who have contraindications.

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine and duloxetine, are primarily used as antidepressants and are not typically used as first-line or preferred treatments for ADHD. These medications target different neurotransmitter systems and do not specifically address the core symptoms of ADHD as effectively as stimulants or atomoxetine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: alpha agonist: This is incorrect because methylphenidate is a stimulant and a common first-line treatment for ADHD, although it is not an alpha agonist. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain.

 

Option B. Dexmethylphenidate or Dextroamphetamine: Dexmethylphenidate is a derivative of methylphenidate and is also a drug of choice for ADHD, working similarly to increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels.

 

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant that is often used in the management of ADHD due to its efficacy in increasing dopamine and norepinephrine release, which helps in reducing ADHD symptoms.

 

Option C. Atomoxetine: antidepressant: Although it is referred to as an antidepressant, atomoxetine is actually a non-stimulant specifically approved for the treatment of ADHD, making it a valid option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.

 

Remember -

 

  • Drugs used:
  • Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • Dx methylphenidate
  • Dextro amphetamine
  • Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • Imipramine
  • Clonidine, guanfacine

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

 

  • A 1-day-old neonate not passing urine since birth is a normal finding in neonates. Continuing breastfeeding and observation is the next step in management.
  • Delay in passing urine or stool is a cause for concern and requires investigation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Admit to NICU: This is not necessary as the absence of urination within the first 24 hours can be normal. Admission to NICU is reserved for cases where the neonate shows signs of distress or other serious conditions.

 

Option C. Start artificial feeding: This option is incorrect as breastfeeding should be continued unless there is a clear medical indication to switch to artificial feeding.

 

Option D. Start intravenous fluids: Starting IV fluids is not necessary unless the child shows signs of dehydration or is unable to take fluids orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

The clinical presentation of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad associated with this condition includes:

 

  1. Intracranial diffuse calcifications
  2. Chorioretinitis
  3. Hydrocephalus

 

These features are clearly visible in the provided imaging, where multiple calcifications (white dots) are seen throughout the brain, which is typical of toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infection in a congenital context typically presents with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse intracranial calcifications. This means the calcifications are primarily located around the brain's ventricles rather than spread diffusely throughout.

 

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika virus infection can lead to gray matter and white matter calcifications, which are distinct from the diffuse calcifications seen in toxoplasmosis. Zika is also associated with microcephaly and contractures, which are not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can present with various symptoms such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing impairment, but it is not typically associated with intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Remember:

 

  • Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics

 

The recommended duration for isolation in cases of bacterial meningitis is until 24 hours after the initiation of effective antibiotic therapy. This is crucial for preventing the spread of infections caused by organisms such as Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). After 24 hours of effective treatment, the risk of transmission significantly decreases, allowing the patient to be removed from isolation.

 

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

 

  • Standard precautions should be implemented for all patients admitted with meningitis.
  • Patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Hib meningitis should be placed on droplet precautions until they have received 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.
  • Patients with these infections should be placed in private rooms during this isolation period.
  • Hospital personnel should wear a face mask when within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Till cultures become negative: This is not a practical or recommended criterion for lifting isolation because cultures can take several days to become negative, and the patient is not typically contagious after 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option C. Till antibiotic course is complete: The full course of antibiotics may last 7-14 days, during which time isolation is not necessary after the first 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option D. Till 12 hours after admission: This is incorrect as it does not meet the standard infection control guidelines. The 24-hour mark after starting effective antibiotics is the critical time point for lifting isolation.

 

Educational Objective:


Children with bacterial meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Haemophilus influenzae should be isolated for 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic therapy to prevent transmission.

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition commonly seen in infants where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to a narrowing of the pyloric canal. This condition presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding, typically around the age of 3 to 6 weeks. The physical finding of an "olive-shaped" mass in the abdomen is characteristic of this condition, which represents the enlarged pyloric muscle.

 

The X-ray findings in pyloric stenosis often show a single bubble sign due to gastric distension without further passage of air into the intestines. This is because the pyloric canal is obstructed, preventing stomach contents from moving into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: This term is more general and can refer to various types of obstructions within the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of an infant with projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass, this is not specific enough and does not pinpoint the pyloric obstruction characteristic of pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is characterized by a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, which is not present in this case. This condition leads to bilious vomiting due to a congenital closure or absence of the duodenal lumen, distinguishing it from pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

 

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia would show a "triple bubble" sign on imaging, which indicates obstruction beyond the duodenum in the jejunum. This would also present with bilious vomiting, unlike the non-bilious vomiting seen in pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 years

 

Brain growth reaches its maximum around 2 years of age. This early and rapid growth phase is crucial for the development of cognitive and motor skills, and it aligns with significant milestones in early childhood development, such as language acquisition, sensory processing, and coordination. The early years are critical for brain development, as synaptic connections are formed at a rapid pace during this time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 years: At 6 years of age, the lymphoid tissues reach their maximum size. The lymphoid system includes the tonsils, adenoids, and other components of the immune system, which are prominent in early childhood to protect against infections.

 

Option C. 10 years: This age is not specifically associated with peak growth in any of the major developmental domains mentioned (brain, lymphoid, somatic, or puberty).

 

Option D. 12 years: This age marks the peak growth for somatic (body) growth and the onset of puberty. During this period, there is a significant increase in height and secondary sexual characteristics as the body undergoes maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.

 

Remember:

 

  • Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity. The New Ballard Score is an extended to include extremely pre-term babies i.e. up to 20 weeks.

 

The scoring relies on the intra-uterine changes that the fetus undergoes during its maturation. Whereas the neurological criteria depend mainly upon muscle tone, the physical ones rely on anatomical changes. The neonate (less than 37 weeks of age) is in a state of physiological hypotonia. This tone increases throughout the fetal growth period, meaning a more premature baby would have lesser muscle tone.

 

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below)

 

 

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heel-knee test: Heel to knee test is not a part of ballard score

 

Option B. Finger-nose test: Finger to nose test is done to assess the cerebellar function.

 

Option D. Cubital angle: The cubital angle, also known as the carrying angle, is measured during the Services Selection Board (SSB) testing process. This has no role in ballard score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) should be stored in the lowest compartment of the Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR) due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder Exstrophy  


The correct diagnosis is Bladder Exstrophy, a congenital condition where the bladder is turned inside out and exposed outside the body. It typically presents with an open, red mass in the lower abdominal area, often just below the umbilical cord, which is consistent with the image provided. This condition occurs due to a failure in the development of the abdominal wall and urogenital structures, leading to the bladder being exposed outside the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines, liver, and other organs protrude outside of the abdomen through the umbilical ring but are covered by a thin membrane or sac. The characteristic feature is that the protruding organs are enclosed in a sac, unlike in bladder exstrophy, where no covering sac is present.

 

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is another abdominal wall defect where the intestines protrude outside of the body but without any covering membrane, typically located to the right of the umbilical cord. However, it does not involve the bladder and appears distinctly different as only intestines are seen without any protective sac.

 

 

Option D. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital condition resulting from an incomplete obliteration of the vitellointestinal duct. It is a small pouch on the wall of the lower part of the small intestine and does not involve external defects or protrusions visible on the abdominal surface. It usually presents with painless rectal bleeding or obstruction.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Bladder Exstrophy is characterized by the bladder being exposed outside the body, appearing as a red mass in the lower abdomen with no covering membrane. It differs from other abdominal wall defects like omphalocele and gastroschisis, which involve the protrusion of abdominal contents with or without a protective sac.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is an essential practice for the care of low birthweight infants, particularly in resource-limited settings. The core components of KMC include:

 

  • Skin-to-skin contact: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The baby's hips are abducted and flexed in a "frog position," and the arms are also flexed. This close contact helps regulate the baby's temperature, breathing, and heart rate.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: KMC promotes exclusive breastfeeding, which is crucial for the baby's nutrition and immune protection.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care: KMC supports the early discharge of stable low birthweight infants from the hospital, allowing continued care at home with close follow-up.

 

These components are fundamental to the success of KMC, leading to improved survival rates and health outcomes for low birthweight infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection," which is an essential aspect of general neonatal care but not a specific component of KMC. KMC primarily focuses on skin-to-skin contact, breastfeeding, and early discharge.

 

Option C. Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Also mentions "prevent infection," which, while important, is not a direct component of KMC.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection" instead of "skin-to-skin contact," making it incorrect, as skin-to-skin contact is a critical element of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose


During neonatal resuscitation, suctioning is performed to clear the airway of the newborn to ensure effective breathing. The correct order for suctioning is mouth first, followed by the nose. This order is crucial because suctioning the nose first could cause the newborn to gasp and potentially aspirate any fluids or secretions present in the mouth.

 

Technical Details:

 

  • The suction catheter typically used is 12 or 14 French, and the suction pressure is maintained between 80-100 mmHg.
  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: One mother had brought her child for evaluation of diphtheria in which the child had low-grade fever, pseudomembranes over the tonsils, and one sibling is fully immunized. What will be the prophylaxis given to her sibling? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The Ans. is Erythromycin. In cases where a household member is diagnosed with diphtheria, all close contacts, including fully immunized siblings, should be given prophylactic treatment regardless of their immunization status.

 

The recommended prophylaxis for contacts is oral Erythromycin for seven days or a single dose of benzathine penicillin. This approach aims to prevent the spread of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the development of active diphtheria lesions in contacts, even if they are asymptomatic and immunized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria booster single dose: A booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid is recommended for previously immunized individuals who are diagnosed with diphtheria but are asymptomatic. This does not apply to the contact sibling who is already fully immunized and not infected.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxoid full course: A full course of the diphtheria toxoid is not necessary for a fully immunized sibling who is a contact. This option would be considered for individuals who are not up-to-date with their diphtheria vaccinations.

 

Option D. Nothing is required: This option is incorrect because all household contacts of a diphtheria case should receive prophylactic treatment to prevent possible infection and transmission, even if they are asymptomatic and fully immunized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fully immunized close contacts of a diphtheria case, the recommended prophylaxis is a seven-day course of oral Erythromycin or a single dose of benzathine penicillin.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

 

Phototherapy is a standard treatment for neonatal jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia. The primary purpose of phototherapy is to reduce elevated bilirubin levels in the blood by converting the toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a form that can be more easily excreted by the body.

 

Mechanisms involved in phototherapy:

 

  1. Irreversible Structural Isomerization: This is the most important mechanism of phototherapy. It converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a more water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys in an unconjugated form. Lumirubin is more easily excreted in the urine, reducing serum bilirubin levels.
  2. Reversible Photo-isomerization Reaction: This process converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a non-toxic configurational isomer, which can be excreted in the bile without conjugation.
  3. Photo-oxidation: This is a minor mechanism where bilirubin undergoes oxidation to form colorless products that are also excreted.

 

Contraindications: Phototherapy is contraindicated in conditions like porphyria, where exposure to light can cause severe photosensitivity and blistering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stercobilin: This is a bile pigment formed from the breakdown of bilirubin in the intestines, giving stool its characteristic brown color. It is not directly involved in the process of phototherapy.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is a precursor to bilirubin in the heme breakdown pathway. Phototherapy does not convert bilirubin back to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Urobilin: Urobilin is a product of bilirubin metabolism that is excreted in the urine, giving urine its yellow color. It is not the primary product of phototherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

 

The procedure depicted in the image is orogastric tube insertion. This involves placing a tube through the mouth (orally) and advancing it down into the stomach. Orogastric tubes are commonly used in pediatric patients for several purposes:

 

  • Enteral rehydration: In children with mild-to-moderate dehydration, an orogastric tube can be used to facilitate enteral rehydration, allowing for fluid administration directly into the stomach.
  • Nutritional support: For children who are severely ill or have significant dehydration, orogastric tubes can also be used for nutritional support by delivering necessary nutrients and medications directly to the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubation: Intubation involves placing a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway and is primarily used in situations where airway protection or mechanical ventilation is required. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube insertion is similar to orogastric tube insertion, but the tube is inserted through the nose instead of the mouth. While both procedures aim to reach the stomach, the entry point distinguishes them.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airways are devices inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway, usually during anesthesia or in unconscious patients. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

 

When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects. This milestone typically occurs around 5.5 to 6 months of age. At this stage, the child is beginning to understand the differences between objects, which is why they are capable of transferring an object between hands. This action demonstrates the child's growing cognitive ability to recognize and compare different objects, an important part of early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual motor coordination: Visual motor coordination refers to the ability to use the eyes and hands together to perform tasks, such as reaching for and grasping objects. While this is important for transferring objects, the key developmental significance of transferring an object from one hand to another lies in the child's ability to compare objects.

 

Option C. Ability to handle small objects: The ability to handle small objects, such as developing a pincer grasp, occurs later, typically around 8 to 9 months of age. This milestone involves more fine motor control and precision, which is different from the broader action of transferring objects between hands.

 

Option D. Voluntary release: Voluntary release refers to the ability to let go of an object intentionally, which is generally seen after the palmar grasp reflex disappears around 4 to 6 months. However, the act of transferring an object from one hand to another is more about the child’s ability to compare objects rather than just releasing them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.

 

Developmental Milestones in 1st Yr of Life

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The clinical scenario of a child with resistant rickets and the following laboratory findings—normal serum calcium, normal parathyroid hormone, decreased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, increased urinary phosphate, decreased urinary calcium, and normal ABG and serum creatinine—is highly suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets: This condition is characterized by low serum phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, leading to rickets despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D. It is often caused by mutations affecting phosphate-regulating genes like PHEX.
  • Laboratory Findings: The hallmark of this condition includes low serum phosphate, high alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D dependent rickets: This would typically show low calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone levels due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or action. Serum phosphate may also be low, but the distinguishing factor is the response to vitamin D therapy, which is absent in hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition usually presents with low calcium and high phosphate levels due to insufficient parathyroid hormone. The given case has normal calcium and low phosphate, making hypoparathyroidism unlikely.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: This would typically show elevated serum creatinine along with abnormalities in calcium and phosphate metabolism. The normal creatinine level in this patient rules out chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.
